Oh wait woah. That’s.. That’s our car.. Wait.. We were hit.. How the hell did I survive..? It directly hit u-
Wait. WE. WE were hit. Where’s Tobias? Tobias. Tobias. Tobia-
“T- TOBIAS. TOBIAS. HEY TOBIA-”
No. He can’t be. He can’t be in the car. I need to get him out. I need to-
No, c’mon, my body won’t move, it won’t- C’MON
This was all my fault. He probably didn’t fly out like I did. He still had his seatbelt on. HE STILL HAD HIS SEATBELT ON.
I need to get him out- I need to-
Maybe he made it out? But I don’t see him I don’t see him anywhere-
And the car’s burning brighter. I can’t get near it. I need to get help- I need to- NOW.
Okay, legs are slowly moving. I need them to move faster, I need them to move faster so I can help Tobi-
Where do I go? I don’t see a clinic nearby, but there’s a house, right around the corner. It looks well-tended, occupied. People- people are there who can help.
But wasn’t there a Red Cross clinic nearby..? They would help but- I don’t- I don’t know where we are, I have no idea-
But there’s a chance. I don’t know, I don’t know, I don’t- I need to HURRY.
I’m losing blood, and… and everything’s getting fuzzier.. I- I need to A) go to the nearby house. B) go find the clinic.

The house, yeah, that makes the most sense. It’s the closest. There’s people inside. They’ll help. They’ll help me and they’ll help Tobias and- and everything’s going to be okay. It’ll just have been a bad dream.
I just need- I just need to- ugh, my body just won’t do what I’m telling it to do..
Breathe. Take a step.
Left.
Right
Left.
Right.
Left-
Focus, breathe, almost there. Left, right, left, up the stairs.
There you go, now knock.
“Ye- Yes, hello? Pleas- please could you all- could you all help me and-”
“Please, don’t be scared, our car was just bombed and- What? No, I won’t lead them here-”
“Wait- NO STOP- STOP, A CHILD- TOBIAS- HE NEEDS-”
*Gunshots*

I can’t trust random strangers around here, I’ve learned that lesson too many times in the past few days. Finding a proper medical team, a team dedicated to helping us civilians, is the best answer to this situation.
I just need to get there fast- fast enough before my body starts to shut down. And fast enough so that maybe, just maybe, they’ll get back here in time to find and save Tobias somehow.
He’s not d- He’s not dead. He can’t be. I won’t believe it.
I just need- I just need to- ugh, my body just won’t do what I’m telling it to do..
Breathe. Take a step.
Left.
Right.
Left.
Right.
Left-
“Rebel resistance in the American city of Greenville has ended after a year of fighting and months of bitter siege and bombardment, as insurgents this evening agreed to withdraw in a ceasefire.”
“The battle of Greenville, one of the worst of a civil war that has drawn in global and regional powers, has ended with victory for US President Lawson and his military forces.”
“The ceasefire was negotiated and approved by all the countries within the UN yesterday evening around 7 o’clock in Geneva.”

“Officials stated that the wounded would be allowed to leave first, and that the majority of the estimated 350,000 people still in western Greenville would be allowed to depart later on Wednesday evening.”
“Even with the ceasefire still unstable, people around the world are coming together to aid those in need of assistance after leaving the besieged city.”
...They called it a mix of both fortune and misfortune.
Misfortune, because I was a casualty of one of the final air raids conducted by the US Government, before a last-minute ceasefire agreement was reached with the help of the UN.
Fortune, because thanks to my wounds, I would be one of the first people helicoptered out of the city to get immediate assistance.
Me? I don’t know what I would call it. And now, even as I’m being transported out towards Canada, I don’t know how to feel.
I just feel.. numb.

When the medical team found me on their way to investigate the wreckage, apparently I was completely unconscious and on the brink of death. The nurse emphasized how if they were even five minutes late, I might’ve not made it.
The team had been kind enough to pick a few things up from the ground that flew out of the car with me, like my small backpack with all the personal belongings within.
This recorder was also still hanging from my neck, so they removed it and decided to give it all back to me once I was better. And so I’m thankful, really.
I know I should be feeling relieved. I know I should be looking forward to the treatment and new life I would have in Canada. I know that.
But everytime I try to convince myself to feel this way, one single thought scorches through my entire body, my entire existence.
We, were so close. Why, didn’t this happen sooner?
Tobias, Tobi, my buddy, my partner, the only positive thing that resulted from this damned war… should’ve been here, right next to me.
But he’s not. He’s gone.

People don’t understand. This is not about who is right, or who is wrong. Who is winning, who is losing. This is about people: flesh and blood, human beings. Bleeding, dying, being made orphans, every day.
This ceasefire should have happened sooner. People outside should’ve fought harder.
...But life is precious. It should never be taken for granted. And even though I want to give up, and cease to exist.. I can’t- no, I won’t do it.
I’m going to live, and survive, for the both of us.
It’ll take months to heal. It’ll take years to change. But I’ll try my best, and I’ll make it in Canada. I’ll live.
And I’ll fight till my final days to make sure something like this will never happen again.. And until I can look up at the sky and say, “We made it bud, it’s all over.”
So here’s to the end of this journal, and to a new beginning.
“Canada has issued its very first travel ban to protect their national security.”
“The travel ban focuses on American refugees, claiming they are “detrimental” to the interests of Canada, and suspends the refugee admissions program for all countries for 120 days.”
“Those waiting for admission approval at borders will be sent back in the next upcoming weeks, and will have to find new methods to leave the war-torn country.”
“While the ban is facing many legal challenges, it is still on track of going into effect this afternoon. That is all for the 8 o'clock news.”
